tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Here are summaries of important legal or procedural changes that affect the latest edition of this product. If you want to check on the accuracy of any other information in the book, please follow the legal research instructions in the book or in Nolo's research manual,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p i span
content: Legal Research: How to Find and Understand the Law

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul b li a span
content: USCIS Switching to Passport-Style Photo Requirement

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul b li a span
content: All Visits to Some USCIS Offices Will Require Appointments

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li b a span
content: Students and Tourists Affected by New Visa Rules and Procedures

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h3 span
content: USCIS Switching to Passport-Style Photo Requirement

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td dd i span
content: Effective date: Jul. 26, 2004

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: In the past, all photos accompanying applications to USCIS had to follow so-called "ADIT" style, meaning the photos showed a � view of the applicant' s face. However, USCIS is changing its policy, and will now accept passport-style photos (showing a full frontal view of the applicant's face). Beginning September 1, 2004, USCIS will require that all photos included with newly filed applications be in passport style.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: For more information on passport photo requirements, go to the State Department's website at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: Back to Top

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h3 span
content: All Visits to Some USCIS Offices Will Require Appointments

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td dd i span
content: Effective date: Jun. 1, 2004

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: To reduce the long lines around USCIS offices, the agency is beginning a new program requiring visitors to make appointments before they arrive. The program, called "InfoPass," is already in effect in Los Angeles, Miami, and New York. It will soon be expanded to other cities.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: If you need to visit USCIS -- whether to submit an application, pick up a form, or ask a question -- check the USCIS website first to see whether InfoPass is in effect at your local USCIS district office. If it is, you have little choice but to make an appointment (some offices will allow walk-ins if there's space, but don't count on this).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Appointments can be made only through the Internet. If you don't have a computer with Internet access, go to your local library, or a nonprofit organization that serves immigrants. Look for a computer with a printer -- you'll need a printout of your appointment notice when you visit. (Also, be sure to bring photo identification and any paperwork associated with your immigration case to your appointment.)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: To make your appointment, go to

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: www.uscis.gov

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: and click the InfoPass link on the right side of the page. You'll be asked to enter information and can request when you want your appointment. You can use this same website to cancel your appointment, if necessary.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: Back to Top

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h3 span
content: Students and Tourists Affected by New Visa Rules and Procedures

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td dd i span
content: Effective date: Apr. 8, 2002

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Various rules for obtaining student and tourist visas have changed or been added in the years since September 11, 2001. In addition, various changes to visa procedures in general will affect tourists and students.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: New Post 9/11 Security Measures

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Since September 11, 2001, Congress and the immigration authorities have introduced various security measures:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If you're applying for a tourist visa or student visa, don't be surprised if you receive more intense questioning than usual. U.S. laws already required consulates to check every applicant for a record of criminal or terrorist acts -- but now they are being even more diligent in following these procedures and are forwarding suspicious cases to the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Immigrants traveling inside the United States should carry their USCIS identity documents at all times. Immigration inspectors may ask immigrants for passports, and/or visa paperwork on airline flights between U.S. cities and inspectors are making use of little-noticed provisions in the law that require nonresidents to carry their green cards or visas and I-94 cards with them wherever they go.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: The laws regarding treatment of immigrant terrorists have been amended. The new laws expand the definition of "terrorist" and give the U.S. Attorney General the right to immediately expel from the United States anyone with suspected terrorist links. It also includes mandatory detention of suspected terrorists.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Special Registration for Certain Visitors to the U.S.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Another of the U.S. government's many post-9/11 security measures has imposed extra monitoring on certain people coming to the United States on nonimmigrant (temporary) visas. If you're soon to arrive in the States, you probably won't know before you get here whether you'll be subject to this additional monitoring; the government is trying to keep its criteria secret.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: If the border officer decides that you fall under the new registration rules, you will have to do all of the following:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Be fingerprinted, photographed, and interviewed about your plans for your stay upon entering the U.S.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Send written notification to the immigration authorities on Form AR-11SR (available at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li a span
content: www.uscis.gov

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: ) if you change your address, your employer, or your school (this doesn't apply to people who stay in the U.S. for fewer than 30 days).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Leave the U.S. only through a designated port of departure (there are currently about 55 such designated ports).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Meet in person with an immigration officer at your port of departure on the day you leave.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: You will be given a packet of information more fully explaining these requirements when you enter the United States.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Special Registration for Certain Men Already in the U.S.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Another of the U.S. government's security measures has imposed extra monitoring on certain men who are already in the United States on nonimmigrant visas. Most of the men affected are students and men on extended business or tourist visits. You needed to register at a local USCIS office under Phase II if you are a man who:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: was born on or before December 2, 1986

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: is a citizen or national of one of the countries listed below

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: entered the United States on or before certain dates in 2002 (listed below) on a nonimmigrant (temporary) visa, and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: planned to stay in the United States until at least your required registration date (see below).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: If you fit this criteria and failed to register by the dates below, the USCIS has the power to deport you. If you find yourself in this position, consult an experienced immigration attorney.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Countries Affected.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The following countries are affected:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Afghanistan

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Algeria

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Bahrain

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Bangladesh

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Egypt

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Eritrea

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Indonesia

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Iran

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Iraq

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Jordan

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Kuwait

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Lebanon

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Libya

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Morocco

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: North Korea

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Oman

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Pakistan

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Qatar

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Saudi Arabia

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Somalia

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Sudan

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Syria

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Tunisia

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: the United Arab Emirates, and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Yemen.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Registration Dates.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Men from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Sudan, and Syria who arrived before September 10, 2002 were required to register by February 7, 2003.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Men from Afghanistan, Algeria, Bahrain, Eritrea, Lebanon, Morocco, North Korea, Oman, Qatar, Somalia, Tunisia, the United Arab Emirates, and Yemen who arrived before October 1, 2002 were required to register by February 7, 2003.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Men from Pakistan and Saudi Arabia who arrived before October 1, 2002 were required to register by March 21, 2003.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Men from Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Jordan, and Kuwait who arrived before October 1, 2002 were required to register by April 25, 2003.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Exceptions.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: You weren't required to register if you were:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: a diplomat or other person admitted on an A or G visa

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: a lawful permanent resident (green card holder) or other immigrant alien, such as an approved asylee or refugee, or

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: an asylum applicant who filed before November 22, 2002.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Changes to Student Visa Procedures

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The most significant change to the student visa application process affects would-be students who are already in the United States on another type of visa. These students will need to obtain approval from U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS, formerly known as the INS) before starting school. Before, foreign students could submit applications for student status but begin school before receiving the USCIS's okay. Under the new rule, USCIS promises to issue its approvals (or denials) within approximately 30 days -- in return for which it requires applicants to wait for its decision before starting school.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Another major change for international students is the setup of the SEVIS system, a database into which the schools will enter information on students, which USCIS can then access via the Internet.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: In theory, students should hardly notice this change, except that it puts them under pressure to inform their foreign student officers quickly of any changes in their address, student status, or other relevant information. In practice, the system has caused frustration, as information doesn't always get entered into the system accurately.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: In addition, international students are being closely monitored. When a school issues an I-20 to a student, it will be required to notify the U.S. consulate in the student's home country. When that consulate approves the student's visa, it will be required to notify the USCIS. During the student's time at school, the school will have to keep the USCIS up to date on the student's status and whereabouts through a database called SEVIS.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: To finance this database, international students now must pay $100 in addition to the usual visa fees. The information and documents that schools are required to make available to USCIS include each international student's:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: name, date and place of birth, country of citizenship

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: current address

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: visa classification, date of visa issuance or classification granted

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: in-school status (full-time or part-time)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: date when studies began

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: degree program and field of study

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: whether the student has been certified for practical training, and the dates of such certification

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: date that studies were terminated, and the reason, if known

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: written application for admission, transcripts or other course records, proof of financial responsibility, and other documents that the school evaluated in admitting the student

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: number of credits completed per semester

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: photocopy of Form I-20ID, and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: record of any academic disciplinary actions due to criminal convictions.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Changes to Photo Requirements for Nonimmigrant Visas

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The State Department has announced new requirements regarding the photos that must be submitted along with any application for a nonimmigrant (temporary) visa -- this includes student and tourist visas. The main difference is that the photos must be bigger -- two inches square, with your head measuring between 1 inch and 1 3/8 inches. In addition, the State Department emphasizes that they want to see the applicant's full head, including hair and, if possible, ears. Head coverings and hats are only acceptable when due to the person's religious beliefs, and even then may not cover any portion of the applicant's face.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Also, photocopies of photographs will not be accepted. Digitally reproduced photos must be of high qualify, with no visible pixels or dot patterns. The photo must be stapled or glued directly on to Form DS-156 in the designated space.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Changed Your Address? The Immigration Authorities Want to Know Right Away

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: In 2002, the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS, now know as the USCIS) started to enforce little-known provisions of the immigration law that make it a crime for immigrants not to submit immediate notifications whenever they change their address. The potential punishments include fines, imprisonment, or deportation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Here's how to protect yourself: First, figure out whether the law applies to you. It covers all foreign nationals who've been in the United States for more than 30 days, including those with:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: nonimmigrant status (a temporary visa or permission to be in the United States, including a student visa, visitor visa, asylum or refugee status, and more), with the exception of those with an �A� or �G� visa

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: green cards (lawful permanent or conditional residence), and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: no status (undocumented or illegal aliens).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The USCIS requires that you use Form AR-11, sending it to a special address set up to handle the mountain of forms it's receiving. And you can't just send one form per family -- every member of your household needs to have a separate form submitted for him or her. The form and the address to which it must be sent are on the USCIS website (in various languages) at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Form AR-11 itself is fairly self-explanatory. If you don't have an A-number (a number the USCIS assigns to people who've applied for green cards or have been in removal proceedings), either ignore this question or supply your I-94 number. The question about your �last address� refers only to your last address in the United States, not overseas. The address you supply should be where you actually live, not a P.O. Box or work address. There is no fee for filing Form AR-11.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: If you have any applications on file that are waiting for a USCIS decision -- for example, you�ve applied for a work permit -- you need to file the change of address form at whichever USCIS office is handling your application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The time window for filing your change of address is only ten days from the date of your move. What if more than ten days have already passed and you�ve only just discovered your responsibility? Most attorneys advise that you fill out the form now, to show the USCIS you made an attempt to comply and to assure that it has your current address.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Be sure to make a photocopy of your Form AR-11 and any notifications you send to other USCIS offices. Then mail everything by certified mail with a return receipt. The return receipt is particularly important because the USCIS won't send you any separate acknowledgment that it has received your form.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Full Middle Name Now Required in All Immigration Forms

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: For security reasons, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS, formerly known as the INS) now asks everyone submitting applications to write in their full middle name -- not just their middle initial. USCIS would like you to do this even if the form you're filling out only asks for your middle initial. If you forget, your application won't be denied, but you will get a letter asking for your full middle name, which is guaranteed to slow down the USCIS's final decision on your application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Young Men Applying for Tourist or Student Visas Must File Extra Form

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Responding to concerns about the involvement of young men in terrorist acts in the United States, the State Department in 2002 instituted stricter visa requirements for males. All 16- to 45-year-old male applicants for "nonimmigrant" (temporary) visas now have to submit Form DS-157 in addition to the usual application materials. This will affect mainly those applying for student and tourist visas. To get a copy of the new form, go to the State Department's website at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: www.state.gov

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: . Click on "Visas," then click "Visa Application Forms" and look for Form DS-157.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: This new form will be mandatory for young men from all countries in the world, not just for men from countries suspected of terrorist links. However, men from Middle Eastern countries are facing longer waits for visas than other applicants.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Check Your Immigration Application's Progress Online

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: You can now check the status of your application online, at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: . Be forewarned, however -- unless your computer has a fairly new browser, you will not be able to access this service.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Once you've accessed the appropriate Web page, you will need the application receipt number from your USCIS receipt notice. If the USCIS has failed to send you a receipt notice, you are unfortunately stuck with using the old phone system.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Revised Forms Required for Many Immigration Applications

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS, formerly called the INS) and the U.S. State Department regularly revise the forms used for immigration applications. The new versions of some of these forms must be used instead of the old versions, even if the changes to the form are minor. In some cases, the agency will accept an earlier version of the form for a while. If you do use an earlier version for some reason, be careful when following the instructions -- in particular, the fees stated on the form are likely to have gone up. In addition, there are some new forms:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li strong span
content: Form DS-158, Contact Information and Work History for Nonimmigrant Visa Applicant.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: This form is now required of all applicants for F, M, or J student visas. It collects family and employment information.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li strong span
content: Form DS-157, Supplemental Nonimmigrant Visa Application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td ul li span
content: This form is now required of all male applicants for nonimmigrant visas who are between the ages of 16 and 45, regardless of which country they are from. It is designed to bring out information regarding potential terrorist tendencies.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: And there's one form you no longer need to send yourself: Form I-538, the certification by your designated school official (DSO) that must accompany applications requesting a school transfer, reinstatement of status, or various work permits.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: The new SEVIS computer system allows your DSO, in most cases, to transmit his or her certification directly to USCIS, without using the Form I-538. Your school may nevertheless ask you to fill out your portion of the form, for its files.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Copies of new USCIS forms (indicated by the initial letter "I") can be obtained from your local USCIS office or by calling USCIS at 800-870-3676. You can also access the latest USCIS forms online at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: www.uscis.gov

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: (click on "Immigration Forms, Fees and Fingerprints," then on "Forms and Fees," and scroll down until you find the appropriate form).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Copies of new State Department forms (indicated by the initial letters "DS") can be obtained from your local consulate.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Visa Waiver Entrants Will Need Passports Containing Biometric Information

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: If you're planning to visit the United States using a visa waiver rather than an actual visa, you may need to get a new passport first. Starting October 26, 2005, all visa waiver entrants must present passports containing a digital photograph.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: By the following year, October 26, 2006, they'll need to have passports containing other biometric information (probably fingerprints), to be announced later.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p span
content: Unfortunately, not all countries whose citizens are eligible for the Visa Waiver Program have the technology to provide this type of passport. If your country doesn't create such passports by the deadline, you'll have to contact your local U.S. embassy and apply for a tourist visa.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td span table tbody tr td p a span
content: Back to Top

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p a b span
content: Fianc� & Marriage Visas: A Couple's Guide to U.S. Immigration

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Married or engaged to a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, and need to get a visa? Find everything you need in this book.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p a b span
content: How to Get a Green Card

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: This essential book gives you all the critical information you need to get a green card.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p a b span
content: Becoming a U.S. Citizen: A Guide to the Law, Exam & Interview

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Covering the topics that most immigration guides don't, this book is the most complete resource available today.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p a b span
content: U.S. Immigration Made Easy

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Use this do-it-yourself book to enter, live in and work in the U.S. temporarily or permanently.
